title: About the Author
text:
I’m currently a graduate student in the Geoinformatics Master’s Program at Hunter College, where I’ve been building skills in GIS and coding. For this project, I wanted to combine those skills with something I’m genuinely passionate about: skiing. As an avid skier who loves exploring new mountains across the Northeast, I created Ski The NorthEast as a way to bring together geographic insight and useful planning tools for fellow skiers and snowboarders.
One question I often hear — and ask myself — is: Where should I go for my next weekend ski trip? Should I visit a new mountain? What’s the surrounding town like? To help answer those questions, this project merges information about medium to large ski mountains in New York, Vermont, and New Hampshire with demographic data from the U.S. Census. By integrating stats like population, age, and income for the counties near each resort, Ski The NorthEast offers a broader picture of not just where to ski, but what kind of experience to expect off the slopes.

title: The slopes are calling…
text:
Take your passion for skiing and Ski The NorthEast. From the Adirondack Mountains of New York, to the White Mountains of New Hampshire. New York, Vermont and New Hampshire have a huge variety of terrain spanning all difficulties.
This project merges information about medium to large ski mountains in New York, Vermont, and New Hampshire with demographic data from the U.S. Census. By integrating stats like population, age, and income for the counties near each resort, Ski The NorthEast offers a broader picture of not just where to ski, but what kind of experience to expect off the slopes.

title: Ski The NorthEast Map
text:
About this Map ::: callout-tip ## Tip
If you would like to see more information on each pass. Scroll past the map to learn more. :::

title: Multi-Mountain Passes Map
text: This map is designed for skiers and snowboarders who either already have a multi-resort pass or are deciding which one to purchase. Whether you’re planning your next trip using a pass you’ve already bought or comparing pass options based on mountain access, this map highlights all medium to large ski areas in New York, Vermont, and New Hampshire that are part of the Ikon, Epic, or Indy Pass networks as of 2025.

title: Sources
text:
Mountain Data Set:
Point location data, including latitude and longitude, were extracted from Google Maps and formatted for compatibility with ArcGIS Online, where they were uploaded for visualization and integration with other spatial datasets. Additional point/mountain data was scraped from Ski Central Website as well as independent mountain websites.
County Data Set:
Polygon data was downloaded from the U.S. Census Bureau using TIGER/Line Shapefiles as well as the U.S. Census Bureau, 2019–2023 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates for population, age, and income.

title: Mountain List & Trail Maps
text: This page provides a comprehensive directory of medium to large ski mountains in New York, Vermont, and New Hampshire. For each mountain, you’ll find links to its official website, current snow report, and trail map. Use the list on the left to browse by state or select a specific mountain.

title: About the Author
text:
My name is Caroline Maramara
I’m currently a graduate student in the Geoinformatics Master’s Program at Hunter College, where I’ve been building skills in GIS and coding. For this project, I wanted to combine those skills with something I’m genuinely passionate about: skiing. As an avid skier who loves exploring new mountains across the Northeast, I created Ski The NorthEast as a way to bring together geographic insight and useful planning tools for fellow skiers and snowboarders.
One question I often hear — and ask myself — is: Where should I go for my next weekend ski trip? Should I visit a new mountain? What’s the surrounding town like? To help answer those questions, this project merges information about medium to large ski mountains in New York, Vermont, and New Hampshire with demographic data from the U.S. Census. By integrating stats like population, age, and income for the counties near each resort, Ski The NorthEast offers a broader picture of not just where to ski, but what kind of experience to expect off the slopes.
